Compute response distribution indices

Source: R/resp_distributions.R
resp_distributions.Rd

Calculates response distribution indicators for multi-item scales or matrix questions which have the same number of response options for many questions.

Usage

resp_distributions(x, min_valid_responses = 1)

Arguments

x

A dataframe containing survey responses in wide format.

min_valid_responses

numeric between 0 and 1. Defines the share of valid responses a respondent must have to calculate response quality indicators. Default is 1.

Details

The functions assumes that the input data frame is structured in the following way:

  • The data frame is in wide format, meaning each row represents one respondent, each column represents one variable.

  • The variables are in same the order as the questions respondents saw while taking the survey.

  • Reverse keyed variables are in their original form. No items were recoded.

  • All responses have integer values.

  • Missing values are set to NA.

The following response distribution indicators are calculated per respondent:

  • n_valid: number of within person valid answers

  • n_na: number of within person missing answers

  • prop_na: proportion of missing responses within respondents

  • ii_mean: intra-individual mean over all items

  • ii_median: intra-individual median

  • ii_median_abs_dev: intra-individual median absolute deviation

  • ii_sd: intra-individual standard deviation

  • ii_var: intra-individual variance

  • mahal: Mahalanobis distance per respondent. Represents the distance of observations from the center of a multivariate normal distribution.

Reponse distribution measures @returns Returns a data frame with response quality indicators per respondent. Dimensions:

  • Rows: Equal to number of rows in x.

  • Columns: 9, one for each response distribution indictator

See also

resp_styles() for calculating response style indicators.

Author

Matthias Roth, Matthias Bluemke & Clemens Lechner

Examples

# A small test data set with ten respondents
# and responses to three survey questions
# with response scales from 1 to 5.
testdata <- data.frame(
  var_a = c(1,4,3,5,3,2,3,1,3,NA),
  var_b = c(2,5,2,3,4,1,NA,2,NA,NA),
  var_c = c(1,2,3,NA,3,4,4,5,NA,NA))

# Calculate response distribution indicators
resp_distributions(testdata) |>
    round(2)
#>    n_valid n_na prop_na wr_mean wr_sd wr_var wr_median wr_median_abs_dev mahal
#> 1        3    0    0.00    1.33  0.58   0.33         1                 0  2.04
#> 2        3    0    0.00    3.67  1.53   2.33         4                 1  1.60
#> 3        3    0    0.00    2.67  0.58   0.33         3                 0  1.38
#> 4        2    1    0.33      NA    NA     NA        NA                NA    NA
#> 5        3    0    0.00    3.33  0.58   0.33         3                 0  0.97
#> 6        3    0    0.00    2.33  1.53   2.33         2                 1  1.38
#> 7        2    1    0.33      NA    NA     NA        NA                NA    NA
#> 8        3    0    0.00    2.67  2.08   4.33         2                 1  1.88
#> 9        1    2    0.67      NA    NA     NA        NA                NA    NA
#> 10       0    3    1.00      NA    NA     NA        NA                NA    NA

# Include respondents with NA values by decreasing the
# necessary number of valid responses per respondent.

resp_distributions(testdata,
                   min_valid_responses = 0.2) |>
    round(2)
#>    n_valid n_na prop_na wr_mean wr_sd wr_var wr_median wr_median_abs_dev mahal
#> 1        3    0    0.00    1.33  0.58   0.33       1.0               0.0  2.27
#> 2        3    0    0.00    3.67  1.53   2.33       4.0               1.0  1.68
#> 3        3    0    0.00    2.67  0.58   0.33       3.0               0.0  1.05
#> 4        2    1    0.33    4.00  1.41   2.00       4.0               1.0  2.21
#> 5        3    0    0.00    3.33  0.58   0.33       3.0               0.0  1.24
#> 6        3    0    0.00    2.33  1.53   2.33       2.0               1.0  1.29
#> 7        2    1    0.33    3.50  0.71   0.50       3.5               0.5  0.71
#> 8        3    0    0.00    2.67  2.08   4.33       2.0               1.0  2.24
#> 9        1    2    0.67    3.00   NaN    NaN       3.0               0.0  0.24
#> 10       0    3    1.00      NA    NA     NA        NA                NA    NA
